There is an extensive marginal annotation that is illegible on the photocopy. Melbourne botanic Garden

The formation of the phytologic section of the technologic Museum, dear Mr Bright, leads me to manyfold thoughts in reference to the administration of that branch of the service. You can readily feel with me when I say, that many of my own researches are bound up with this particular branch of the Museum service and that I take a deep interest in the display of a collection, for which I have studied and actively worked for many years. In reflecting on the circumstance, that moreover this vegetable portion of the Museum will require my constant professional counsels and my frequent personal visits to the Museum, I have meditated much, how on the one hand I could be most readily useful to your institution, and on the other hand maintain that professional dignity, which is — I can fairly say — my only treasure in the world. I have thought it best to offer frankly my views on this subject with a hope, that you will submit these views to the consideration of the trustees. To avoid then any misunderstandings at the very commencement of the practical organisation of the Museum, I would beg of you and your colleagues to allot this portion of the museum, embracing the vegetable products, to my administration as a consulting and honorary officer of the trustees. By such arrangements all circumlocution, hindrances, diversities of opinions on arrangement &c would be avoided, as I could from time to time do myself the honor of attending at the meetings of the trustees, to obtain their directions
See also M to J. MacPherson, 11 May 1870 (in this edition as 70-05-11d).

Secondly I beg to point out, that in the section for products from plants, constant occupation will exist for some young intelligent person, to add to the collections, maintain them in order, see to the labeling & a multitude of other smaller duties, which can only be carried out under my immediate superintendence. It would therefore very much simplify work, and certainly also encourage me very much, if I was finally allowed to select a youth at a modest weekly remuneration to work under my supervision in this branch of the Museum.
